newsitem.title: PUERTO RICO: Puerto Rico moves to ban bungee jumping.
newsitem.headline: Puerto Rico moves to ban bungee jumping.

text.p: Engineers inspected bungee jumping operations and carnival rides in Puerto Rico on Thursday and lawmakers moved to ban the pastime after the death of a 17-year-old jumper last week.

Lawmakers have filed three separate bills in Puerto Rico's legislature this week that would make bungee jumping a crime. At this same time, the mayor of San Juan announced she was writing an ordinance to outlaw bungee jumping in the city.
The bills were spurred by the death on March 22 of Roberto Lopez Carrasquillo, who crashed to the ground while bungee jumping at the Ciudad Mecanica carnival in San Juan.
Carnival officials say the cord tied to Lopez Carrasquillo's leg apparently snapped during the 90-foot (27.43 metre) fall.

"Bungee jumping is a high-risk activity and it isn't the first time that a tragedy occurred," said Senate president Charlie Rodriguez, who filed one of the bills. "We can't allow in Puerto Rico that people keep on putting their lives at risk by flinging themselves into the air."

Rodriguez's bill proposed up to six months in jail and fines of up to $500 for operators of bungee jumping equipment. A tougher measure filed in the House would impose up to three years in jail for jump operators and fines of $10,000 for operators and $2,000 for jumpers.
The San Juan district attorney's office was investigating the fatal jump of Lopez Carrasquillo, who was buried on Monday.

Ciudad Mecanica promoter Carlos Garcia said the jump operator, Texas-based Bungee Plunge Inc., changed the rope after every 800 jumps. Lopez Carrasquillo's jump was number 722 for the rope, Garcia said.
San Juan Safety Commissioner Jorge Collazo, ordered the closure of seven bungee machines on the island.
"There is no doubt we will get this municipal ordinance approved (to ban bungee jumping)," Collazo said. "We've gotten a lot of support from all over the island."
